instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.R7121: What is R7121? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Ornage light not turn on.
threads.message:
This unit was water damged and see damage around i625 and found the following measurment of i625.
Any help please.

p1=0v
p2=16
p3=4.2
p4=2.8v
p5=1
p6=0
p7=0.5
p8=1.5
p9=0
p10=3.4

p11=3.4
p12=3.4
p13=3.4
p14=3.4
p15=0
p16=8
p17=8
p18=8
p19=5
p20=5

p21=0.5
p22=0
p23=8.6
p24=8.6
p25=12.9
p26=15.1????
p27=2
p28=0v

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Ornage light not turn on.
threads.message:
"p17=8
p18=8"
Post exact value; i.e. 8.22V, or 8.56V...

"p27=2
p28=0v"
Both <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22 bad.
Be sure no short to ground at pin 28, after changed them.

BTW,
"i625"
<CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>...

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Ornage light not turn on.
threads.message:
p17=8.61
p18=8.61
i couldnt find <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22 and now i found the value ( before i was wrong )
"p27=16.09
p28=16.09v

yes i625is <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>.

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Ornage light not turn on.
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR>/22 in this case, but new values are good; forgot about the reistors.
Does it start in SMC bypass mode?
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and see if <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> drops to 0V at the same moment.

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Ornage light not turn on.
threads.message:
Doesnt  start in SMC bypass mode.

Yes,Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and   <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> drops to 0V at the same moment.

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Ornage light not turn on.
threads.message:
Any pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> at same time?
Also check for pulses at big coils.

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Ornage light not turn on.
threads.message:
dont have ocs, using true rms and  see, at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>  .22 mv at same time
Also found different voltage  at big coils.

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Ornage light not turn on.
threads.message:
Don't need special equipment.
Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> repeatedly and check if any voltage tries to appear at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> signal.
You should get a reading of 1-2V at least, even 3V...

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Ornage light not turn on.
threads.message: Trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> repeatedly and check NO  voltage trips to appear at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> signal, check couple of time.

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Ornage light not turn on.
threads.message:
If <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> reacts, but NO <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> reaction at same time, then PCH issue.
Be sure first the PCH gets S5 and SUS voltages...

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Ornage light not turn on.
Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Ornage light not turn on.
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPVOUT_S5_PCH_DCPSUSBYP_R</SIGNAL>, <RESISTOR>R0899</RESISTOR>=1.07v ????"
As per schematic, VOLTAGE=1.05V...

Put good flux and heat PCH.
You may have luck to be only crap under PCH.

threads.title: Macbook Air <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A Ornage light not turn on.
threads.message: put flux and heat pch, no luck ,thanks for helping me but i learn something today.
